channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine’s Moves Against Protesters Raise Tensions
item.description: Ominous new action by Ukraine’s security forces on Monday appeared to scuttle an opening for talks between the government and demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Soldiers on Monday blocked the way to Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine.

item.title: German Coalition Hinges on Vote Among Social Democrats
item.description: A deal by Chancellor Angela Merkel with her Social Democratic rivals for a coalition government must be approved by the party’s members, which some see as possibly unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: The Lede: Updates on Mourning for Mandela
item.description: The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela, on a day of tributes to the man who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and then served as its first freely elected president.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Scores of World Leaders to Attend Mandela Memorial
item.description: The memorial will be held in the World Cup soccer stadium in Soweto, South Africa, where Nelson Mandela made his last public appearance in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Israel Agrees to Allow Building Materials Into Gaza
item.description: After an eight-week hiatus, construction materials will be allowed in again starting Tuesday, but only for United Nations projects.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Navy Secretary Expands Review of Supply Contracts
item.description: Amid an inquiry into bribery in the Pacific, Secretary Ray Mabus has ordered an examination of how the service awards contracts around the globe.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DANIELLE IVORY

item.title: Israel, Jordan and Palestinians Sign Water Project Deal
item.description: Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority agreed to build a Red Sea-Dead Sea water project, including a brine pipeline and desalination plant, that is meant to benefit all three parties.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: The Lede: Ukraine on Edge as Protesters and the Authorities Face Off
item.description: Battalions of police officers confronted demonstrators in Kiev, a day after a huge rally in which a statue of Lenin was toppled in Independence Square.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Thai Premier Calls for Vote, but Protests Continue
item.description: The move by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra did not satisfy antigovernment demonstrators in Bangkok, who vowed to expel her powerful family from the country.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters outside the Government House in Bangkok on Monday.

item.title: The Media Equation: Where Freedom of the Press Is Muffled
item.description: China and Britain both underscore how transparency, however painful in the moment, allows democracy, business and the citizenry to thrive in the long run.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR
item.media:description: Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, testifying last week.

item.title: Iraq Forces Clash With Gunmen in Syria Border Area
item.description: More than 20 people were killed in attacks in Baghdad and north of the capital, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: With No Notice, Putin Scraps Kremlin News Agencies
item.description: The decision to dissolve Ria Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster, came as a complete surprise and signaled a major state media reorganization in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Hagel Meets With Pakistan’s Civilian and Military Leaders
item.description: Chuck Hagel’s brief visit to Pakistan, the first by an American defense secretary in almost four years, came at a time of change for the country’s powerful armed forces.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 9
item.description: Tibetan activists protesting against China in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Tibetan activists shouting slogans against China during a demonstration outside the Chinese embassy in New Delhi. They were protesting China's rule in the Tibetan region.

item.title: News Analysis: A Gamble for North Korea’s Young Leader
item.description: In publicly dismissing his uncle and mentor, Kim Jong-un removed a potential challenger to his power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song Thaek, uncle to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, was forcibly removed from a meeting of the Political Bureau by uniformed personnel in a photograph released Monday by Yonhap news agency.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Looking on the Bright Side of Bad Air
item.description: The heavy air pollution covering much of eastern China recently has prompted intense coverage in the Chinese media, some of it humorous, showing that Chinese residents have a far better idea now of what they are breathing than they did just a few years ago, when such information was considered sensitive.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Searches for "air pollution" in China in recent years, according to Google.

item.title: Spies’ Dragnet Reaches a Playing Field of Elves and Trolls
item.description: American and British spies have infiltrated online fantasy games, fearing that militants could use them to communicate, move money or plot attacks, documents show.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and JUSTIN ELLIOTT

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Survey Finds Many Female Workers Experience Sexual Harassment
item.description: A survey in southern China suggests sexual harassment is widespread among female factory workers, with 70 percent reporting some form of harassment and 15 percent quitting their jobs over it, losing significant income.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Forbes Conrad for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker assembles sauna components at a furniture factory in Guangzhou.

item.title: Philippines and Muslim Rebels Move Closer to Final Peace Deal
item.description: The two sides said they had reached agreement on sharing power in Muslim-dominated parts of the south and hoped to reach a final peace agreement by January.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author James Astill
item.description: Mr. Astill, the author of ‘The Great Tamasha: Cricket, Corruption, and the Turbulent Rise of Modern India, shared his prescription on how to clean up the game in India.
item.dc:creator: By ZACH MARKS
item.media:description: James Astill, author of the book 'The Great Tamasha: Cricket, Corruption and the Turbulent Rise of Modern India' at The Times of India Literary Carnival in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: India Ink: Indian Stock Markets Hit Record High on B.J.P. Victories
item.description: Investors see the Bharatiya Janata Party and its prime ministerial candidate, Narendra Modi, as more likely to back policies that favor businesses and investors than the Congress Party.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Supporters of Bharatiya Janata Party celebrating outside the party office in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on Sunday.

item.title: Venezuelan Mayoral Votes Show No Big Power Shift
item.description: Hundreds of mayoral contests in Venezuela on Sunday are seen as an early test of President Nicolás Maduro and his ability to carry the country further along a socialist path.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: North Korea Releases List of Accusations Against Purged Official
item.description: Confirming the removal of Kim Jong-un’s uncle, Jang Song-thaek, from top posts, the North Korean regime details lengthy charges.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Beijing Journal: A Global Dining Empire Loses an Outpost
item.description: Maison Boulud, part of the chef Daniel Boulud’s international dining empire, closed Sunday after five years, the victim perhaps of the staid habits of Beijing restaurantgoers.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main dining room. The restaurant opened five years ago in the former American Embassy.

item.title: Thai Premier Calls for Elections as Opposition Quits
item.description: The Democrat Party said its members would join street protests against the government, deepening Thailand’s political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters march during a rally in Bangkok on Monday.
